org.gbif.crawler.protocol

Class AbstractResponseHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gbif.crawler.protocol.AbstractResponseHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ResponseHandler<org.apache.http.HttpResponse,List<Byte>>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BiocaseResponseHandler, DigirResponseHandler, TapirResponseHandler

    @NotThreadSafe
public abstract class AbstractResponseHandler
extends Object
implements ResponseHandler<org.apache.http.HttpResponse,List<Byte>>
    A base class for response handlers.

    This class takes care of converting a HttpResponse into a byte[] which is then converted to a List of bytes. You can get the underlying array back by using Guava: Bytes.toArray(java.util.Collection)}.

    A hash code is automatically calculated for the content of the response. The various getters throw an IllegalStateException if the last response was not valid so check isValidState() before calling any of those. An alternative indicator are the exceptions thrown by handleResponse(HttpResponse). If any is thrown during processing the Response handler is in an illegal state until a successful response has been handled.

    This class is not thread-safe.

    • Method Detail

      • process

        protected abstract void process(org.codehaus.stax2.XMLStreamReader2 reader)
                         throws XMLStreamException,
                                FatalCrawlException,
                                ProtocolException
        This needs to be implemented by subclasses to do actual processing on the XML data. This method is called for every single stream event (which includes whitespace etc.) so implementations need to check the event type and make sure to work on the correct elements.
        Parameters:
        reader - to use
        Throws:
        XMLStreamException - if there was an error with the XML parsing (e.g. invalid XML)
        ProtocolException - if there is a problem with the (well-formed) XML response (e.g. missing attribute)
        FatalCrawlException

      • shouldHash

        protected abstract boolean shouldHash(org.codehaus.stax2.XMLStreamReader2 reader)
        Needs to be implemented by subclasses to indicate to the parent class what the XML element is which delimits the actual content of a result. Everything inside this element including the element itself is hashed.
        Returns:
        with the content element name

      • isValidState

        public boolean isValidState()
        Description copied from interface: ResponseHandler
        This can be used to see if this response handler is in an illegal state or not. This can happen after parsing a wrong response or if there has been a transport exception. A proper response needs to be handled for this to be cleared.
        Specified by:
        isValidState in interface ResponseHandler<org.apache.http.HttpResponse,List<Byte>>
        Returns:
        false if the other getter methods will throw a IllegalStateException

      • initialize

        protected abstract void initialize()
        To be implemented to initialize internal state before every new response is being handled.

      • handleResponse

        public final List<Byte> handleResponse(org.apache.http.HttpResponse response)
                                throws FatalCrawlException,
                                       ProtocolException,
                                       TransportException
        This is an implementation that processes a HttpResponse and produces a List of Bytes.
        Specified by:
        handleResponse in interface ResponseHandler<org.apache.http.HttpResponse,List<Byte>>
        Parameters:
        response - to be handled
        Returns:
        the byte array corresponding to the response we received. Wrapped in a List of Bytes because this is extending a typed interface. This list is guaranteed to be convertable to a primitive byte[] using Guava's Bytes.toArray(java.util.Collection)}.
        Throws:
        ProtocolException - if there are any problems with the content received
        TransportException - if there are any problems receiving the response
        FatalCrawlException
